title: fullfile
summary: Build a platform-correct file path from multiple path segments.

gpu_support.notes: Runs entirely on the host CPU. GPU-resident text inputs are gathered before path assembly.

description: `fullfile` joins path segments using the platform-specific file separator, producing a single path string that matches MATLAB semantics. It accepts any number of path segments and returns a character row vector (`1xN`).
behaviors: `fullfile(part1, part2, ...)` joins the inputs with the platform file separator (`/` on macOS and Linux, `\` on Windows).
Absolute path segments reset the accumulated path, mirroring MATLAB and OS path rules.
Empty segments are ignored, so `fullfile("", "data")` returns `data`.
Inputs must be character vectors or string scalars. Single-element string arrays are accepted. Other input types raise `fullfile: arguments must be character vectors or string scalars`.
The output is a character vector. Wrap the result with `string(...)` if you prefer string scalars.

examples.output: % Returns a full path rooted at the current working folder

examples.description: Create A File In A Nested Folder

faqs.question: Why does `fullfile` return a character vector instead of a string?
faqs.answer: MATLAB returns character vectors for `fullfile`. RunMat mirrors that behavior for compatibility; use `string(fullfile(...))` if you prefer string scalars.

faqs.question: Does `fullfile` expand `~` to the home directory?
faqs.answer: No. `fullfile` performs string assembly only. Use `cd` or filesystem APIs that expand `~` when you need home expansion.

faqs.question: What happens if a segment is absolute?
faqs.answer: Absolute segments reset the accumulated path, matching MATLAB and OS path rules.

faqs.question: Can I pass numeric character codes?
faqs.answer: Yes. Numeric arrays that represent character codes are accepted as long as they form a row vector, just like other RunMat text inputs.

faqs.question: Does `fullfile` run on the GPU?
faqs.answer: No. It is a host-only utility and gathers GPU-resident inputs before processing.

gpu_residency: No. `fullfile` is a host-side path builder. GPU-resident text inputs are gathered automatically, so there is no benefit to keeping path strings on the GPU.
gpu_behavior: `fullfile` performs string manipulation on the CPU only. Any GPU-resident inputs are gathered to the host before path assembly so the resulting character vector is always in CPU memory.
